title: Flu vaccinations slightly lagging in Mass. this year amid early surge in flu cases
author: Molly Farrar
bullets: Local News 32 percent of Boston residents are vaccinated, which is lagging slightly behind from 34 percent last year and 36 percent the year before.
AP Photo/Rebecca Blackwell, File By Molly Farrar January 12, 2026 | 6:37 PM 3 minutes to read ShareSend this article to your social connections.

Flu vaccinations both in Boston and across Massachusetts are slightly lagging behind last year’s vaccination rates, city and state data shows, as an early surge of flu cases sends thousands to the hospital and has led to dozens of deaths statewide.

title: Norfolk District Attorney Michael Morrissey won’t seek reelection
author: Abby Patkin
bullets: Politics Morrissey has weathered criticism over his office's handling of several controversial cases.
Norfolk District Attorney Michael Morrissey.

Keith Bedford By Abby Patkin January 12, 2026 | 5:39 PM 2 minutes to read Embattled Norfolk County District Attorney Michael Morrissey announced Monday he will not seek reelection to the office he has held since 2010, ending a decades-long career in public office.

title: Labcorp is closing its Bedford facility, laying off close to 100 positions
author: Beth Treffeisen
bullets: Business The global life sciences and health care company did not explain why it is closing the facility.
Labcorp ran a COVID-19 vaccination site at the Natick Mall.
Suzanne Kreiter/Globe Staff The health care company Labcorp has notified the state that it is laying off 94 employees and closing its Bedford facility.

title: Mass. fire department credits phone app for saving lost hikers
author: Heather Alterisio
bullets: Local News "Using just three simple words, they were able to give our teams their precise location, leading to a much faster rescue," the fire department noted.
Authorities rescued a pair of hikers in Western Massachusetts on Saturday night with the help of a smartphone app, which provided the search team with the pair’s precise location.
The Westfield Regional Public Safety first received a report at 7:20 p.

title: Somerville biotech company laying off 35% of workforce
author: Beth Treffeisen
bullets: Business Tessera Therapeutics, a genetic medicine company, is laying off 90 employees as it refocuses on a new partnership.

Tessera Therapeutics, a high-profile Somerville biotech developing next-generation gene-writing technology, is cutting about 35% of its workforce as it shifts its focus to a new partnership with Regeneron.
The company notified the state on Wednesday that it will lay off 90 employees, including 82 Massachusetts residents, beginning March 8.
